properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A drastic change in conditions is expected for southern Alberta on Friday. An approaching weather system is expected to bring a dramatic change to weather conditions in southern Alberta. In the Calgary, Brooks, Lethbridge, Medicine Hat, Okotoks, and Cypress Hills areas temperatures will start out well above freezing with widely scattered showers. However the cold front with this system will bring gusty northerly winds to 80 km/h and a sharp drop in temperatures. The front may also bring heavier pockets of snow and blowing snow as well. This abrupt change in weather will lead to hazardous travel conditions, and may occur during the Friday afternoon commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T13:15:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T21:16:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1363106933.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first significant snowfall of the season is possible this weekend. An intensifying area of low pressure from the Upper Midwestern United States is expected to bring widespread snowfall. Snow will begin in Northwestern Ontario on Saturday afternoon before reaching the Geraldton area by Saturday evening. Locations near to Lake Superior may receive rain mixed with snow thus limiting snowfall amounts. There remains considerable uncertainty as to the exact track of the system, however, snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible by the time the snow ends on Sunday. Snowfall Warnings may be required as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T13:17:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T21:18:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2603985464.2020
Area: Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the Eastern American Seaboard will track through Eastern Quebec on Saturday. The rain associated with this system could give rainfall amounts higher than 50 millimetres over several areas of Central and Eastern Quebec beginning Friday afternoon. The rain is expected to persist through Saturday. Meanwhile, a few centimetres of snow could accumulate over higher terrain overnight on Friday and Saturday during the day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T12:01:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T20:02:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2323408927.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A moisture-laden Pacific front will move onto the central coast of B.C. today. Rain will begin this morning and become heavy this evening. The front will exit the region early Friday morning. Total rainfall amounts of 100 mm are expected for the coastal sections and up to 80 mm are forecast for the inland sections by Friday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T03:36:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T11:37:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2984518791.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections, Central Coast - inland sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan has been extended and remains in effect until rescinded. The public is being reminded to always practice physical distancing of 2 metres when engaging with others. During all Phases of Re-Open Saskatchewan, all public health orders are to be followed and applied in all public and private gatherings.
Expires: 2020-10-28T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-10-14T15:25:36-06:00, 4EF40AA3-5B3B-1E8D-0CB5-32FECF070837
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By The Village Of Coleville.
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the village of Coleville. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access the Coleville water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2020-10-21T17:00:00-06:00

Area: Village of Coleville

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. An approaching weather system from BC will begin to dump snow onto the Icefields Parkway and the Grande Cache Regions tonight. Total snowfall accumulations may reach 15 to 25 cm by the time the snow ends late Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T13:28:50-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Frost is expected to develop overnight into early Friday as temperatures fall to the freezing mark. Frost is also possible Friday night into Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Westerly winds with gust to 100 km/h are expected to develop early Friday morning. These winds will drop off by the afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. An approaching weather system from BC will bring heavy snow to parts of western and central Alberta starting Friday morning. The highest snowfall amounts should fall southwest of a line extending from Beaverlodge to Red Deer and south towards Kananaskis. Total accumulations are expected to approach 10 cm by late Friday. However local amounts of 15 cm or more may fall over the higher elevations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T13:30:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T21:31:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1209900155.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected continue along the southern shore of Great Slave Lake near and east of the community of Fort Resolution tonight and Friday. Snowfall amounts will range significantly depending on where the snow squall sets up, but local total accumulations by Friday evening could exceed 25 cm. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T13:21:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T21:22:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3970638003.2020
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific low pressure system is expected to begin to move into Alberta late tonight, and track through the province on Friday. Significant snowfall associated with this system is expected to begin this evening with accumulations possibly in excess of 25 cm for portions of the Icefields Parkway by Friday afternoon. Rapidly falling snow with winds gusting near 70 km/h in exposed portions of the highway may lead to poor visibility and local blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. Heavy wet snow is expected tonight. A Pacific low pressure system is forecast to move across the central interior tonight bringing snow to the region this evening. The snow may be initially mixed with rain before intensifying later this evening. Accumulations will be generally near 10 cm but could exceed that amount over higher terrain. The snow will end Friday morning as the low moves into Alberta. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. Heavy wet snow is expected tonight. A Pacific low pressure system is forecast to move across the central interior tonight bringing snow to the region this evening. The snow may be initially mixed with rain before intensifying later this evening. Accumulations will be generally near 10 cm but could exceed that amount over higher terrain. The snow will end Friday morning as the low moves into Alberta. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. An approaching weather system from BC will bring heavy snow to parts of western and central Alberta starting Friday morning. The highest snowfall amounts should fall southwest of a line extending from Beaverlodge to Red Deer and south towards Kananaskis. Total accumulations are expected to approach 10 cm by late Friday. However local amounts of 15 cm or more may fall over the higher elevations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
